awd_titl_txt: Conference: The 23rd Penn State Plant Biology Symposium: RNA Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide partial support for the 23rd Penn State Plant Biology Symposium: RNA Biology, to be held May 18-20, 2022 on the Penn State Campus in College Park. The conference will feature established and emerging leaders in all aspects of plant RNA biology. This is the continuation of two long-running conference series, and is expected to draw an international group of attendees. The conference will include two keynote addresses, 19 invited lectures, and 15 contributed presentations, as well as two poster sessions. Travel awards and outreach will ensure a diverse group of participants. Students will have prominent roles at the conference, helping to organize and run the sessions, as well as presenting their own research. A publication describing findings from the symposium will be led by graduate student attendees, providing valuable professional experience and tangible outcomes for their career advancement. 

RNA biology is a fast-moving field that is impacting all areas of the life sciences. Plants are at the forefront of RNA biology, both as tractable model systems and in the context of enhancing agricultural productivity. Pivotal discoveries in RNA structure, gene regulation, and epigenetics are coming from plant systems. The conference will cover exciting advances in the areas of small regulatory RNAs, RNA structure, RNA processing, RNA localization, translational control of gene expression, and epigenetics and chromatin modifications. This symposium will gather leading investigators, early stage scientists, trainees, and students in an intimate setting. This will allow for information sharing on the cutting edge of this field. The comprehensive plan for recruiting participants will ensure that the gathering will catalyze collaborations that may not otherwise happen.

This project is jointly funded by the Genetic Mechanisms program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Plant Genome Research Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems of the Biological Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
This project partially defraied expenses for the “23rd Penn State Plant Biology Symposium: RNA Biology”. The conference was held May 18-20, 2022, on the University Park campus of The Pennsylvania State University. There were 125 registered attendees at the conference. The attendees included scientists at a variety of career stages, including professors, graduate students, undergraduate students, and other science professionals. The conference featured established and emerging leaders in all aspects of plant RNA biology, who presented on the latest biological and technological advances in this exciting field. This conference was the continuation of two long-running small conference series: The Plant State Plant Biology symposia (of which this was the 23rd), and the Posttranscriptional Gene Regulation in Plants symposia (of which this was the 12th). Both conference series have a strong history of innovative, impactful, and cross-disciplinary activities, and of engaging and showcasing early stage researchers. 

Intellectual Merit

RNA Biology is a fast-moving field that is impacting all areas of the life sciences. Plants are at the forefront of RNA Biology, both as easily studied organisms that illuminate processes occurring in every creature, and in the context of enhancing agricultural productivity. Pivotal discoveries in RNA structure, gene regulation, and epigenetics are coming from plant systems. This meeting convened a meeting where world leaders, early-career investigators, and students at all levels came together. This conference accelerated research by fostering new collaborations and by stimulating new threads of research. 

Broader Impacts

The conference had participation by diverse groups. Speakers were well-balanced by gender and career stage. Participation by early career investigators, trainees, and by members of underrepresented groups was supported through travel awards and by talks selected from poster abstracts. The conference also had participation by undergraduates, including many from Pennsylvania-area primarily undergraduate institutions.  Research and education was integrated by thorough participation by graduate students and undergraduate students. Major findings disclosed in the meeting were shared with the public by publication of a student-written meeting report, which appeared in the journal Plant Direct. Ultimately this conference helped to stimulate progress in the plant RNA Biology field. This progress is expected to benefit society through applications in biotechnology and crop development. 

 


Last Modified: 03/17/2023
Modified by: Michael J Axtell
